statement:
Let $R$ be a subring of a field $K$, $1\in R$ and let $\alpha$ be a
non-zero element of $K$. The following conditions are equivalent:

1.  $\alpha$ is integral over $R$.

2.  $\alpha$ belongs to $R[\alpha^{-1}]$.

3.  $\alpha$ is unit of $R[\alpha^{-1}]$.

4.  $\alpha^{-1}R[\alpha^{-1}] = R[\alpha^{-1}]$.

[*Proof.*]{} Supposing the first condition that an equation
$$\alpha^n+a_1\alpha^{n-1}+\ldots+a_{n-1}\alpha+a_n = 0,$$ with $a_j$’s
belonging to $R$, holds. Dividing both by $\alpha^{n-1}$ gives
$$\alpha = -a_1-a_2\alpha^{-1}-\ldots-a_n\alpha^{-n+1}.$$ One sees that
$\alpha$ belongs to the ring $R[\alpha^{-1}]$ even being a unit of this
(of course $\alpha^{-1}\in R[\alpha^{-1}]$). Therefore also the
principal ideal $\alpha^{-1}R[\alpha^{-1}]$ of the ring $R[\alpha^{-1}]$
coincides with this ring. Conversely, the last circumstance implies that
$\alpha$ is integral over $R$.

[7]{} Emil Artin: [**]{}. Lecture notes. Mathematisches Institut,
Göttingen (1959).
